body: Another note: it seems that CPython 3.8 changed something else too, so, even older versions of pytest fail with CPython 3.8 (i.e.: it works with `CPython 3.7` + `pytest 5.0.1` but fails with `CPython 3.8` and `pytest 5.0.1` -- and `pytest 5.2.1` fails with both).
just because I'm curious: what's the problem here?

The problem is that pytest reports all errors as if they were run from `C:\temp\somedir` instead of `T:` in the example (i.e.: you can see in the output that it sees `C:\temp\somedir` as the rootdir instead of the working directory which would be `T:`).

This is an issue mainly when working with editors/IDEs where you work the file and then when you click the traceback it'll open the file as if it was a different file (i.e.: `T:\test_it.py` was run, but tracebacks will show `C:\temp\somedir\test_it.py`).
Likely caused by the same problem here: #5905

I did some investigation and it appears that the issue is that `pytest` is now using `Path().resolve()` to resolve paths (including the current directory).

This means that the paths reported on a run become wrong (they're no longer reporting the current directory, they are reporting the resolved directory).

i.e.:

```
> c:
> cd \
> mkdir foo
> subst f: c:\foo
> python -c "import pathlib;print(pathlib.Path().resolve())"
  C:\foo
> python -c "import pathlib;print(pathlib.Path().absolute())"
  F:
```

So, given this, creating a file on `F:\test_loc.py` with the contents below:

```
def test_path_error_location():
    raise AssertionError()
```

The output when running it from `F:` is the following:

```
py.test test_loc.py
================================= test session starts ================================== 
platform win32 -- Python 3.7.6, pytest-5.3.2, py-1.8.1, pluggy-0.13.1
rootdir: C:\foo
collected 1 item

test_loc.py F                                                                     [100%]

======================================= FAILURES ======================================= 
_______________________________ test_path_error_location _______________________________

    def test_path_error_location():
>       raise AssertionError()
E       AssertionError

C:\foo\test_loc.py:2: AssertionError
================================== 1 failed in 0.03s ===================================
```

and when running from `C:\foo` is:

```
py.test test_loc.py
================================= test session starts ================================== 
platform win32 -- Python 3.7.6, pytest-5.3.2, py-1.8.1, pluggy-0.13.1
rootdir: C:\foo
collected 1 item

test_loc.py F                                                                     [100%]

======================================= FAILURES ======================================= 
_______________________________ test_path_error_location _______________________________

    def test_path_error_location():
>       raise AssertionError()
E       AssertionError

test_loc.py:2: AssertionError
================================== 1 failed in 0.02s ===================================
```

So, notice how in the examples above the error is reported at the full (wrong) path when running from `F:` and is reported with a relative (correct) path when run from `C:\foo`.

I think changing `Path.resolve` to `Path.absolute` should fix the issue. I'll provide a pull request shortly.

issue.title: Windows symlink broken by Path().resolve()

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: problem that needs to be addressed

labels.name: type: regression
labels.description: indicates a problem that was introduced in a release which was working previously

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.body:
On Windows 10 (v1903, 18362.356) I have created a D: drive using Subst. My tests used to work, but I recently upgraded pytest and found that I now get this error message for every test file:

```
____________________________________________ ERROR collecting test_feature_toggles.py _____________________________________________
import file mismatch:
imported module 'tests.unit.test_feature_toggles' has this __file__ attribute:
  D:\development\psma\api\api-master\api_services\pav\imp\src\tests\unit\test_feature_toggles.py
which is not the same as the test file we want to collect:
  C:\d_drive\development\psma\api\api-master\api_services\pav\imp\src\tests\unit\test_feature_toggles.py
HINT: remove __pycache__ / .pyc files and/or use a unique basename for your test file modules
```

Well, they are the same file, deleting ALL __pycache__/.pyc files has no impact and I believe the problem was introduced in this PR:
https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/pull/5564

I believe this may be the same cause of a different bug: https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/5826

Is it possible to use Path().absolute() instead?

Pytest version: `5.1.3`


To recreate, use subst to map a folder where you have tests into a new drive letter, cd to that folder on the new drive letter and try to run the tests again.

body:
There's another breaking change on Python 3.8:

Until Python 3.7 `os.path.realpath = os.path.abspath` on Windows, whereas on Python 3.8 `os.path.realpath` is resolving the links (which is the reason my pull request for Python 3.8 was failing).

See: https://bugs.python.org/issue9949

I just updated the pull request.

issue.title: Fix issue where working dir becomes wrong on subst drive on Windows. Fixes #5965

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.body:
Note that I didn't change all the `Path.resolve()` occurrences on `pytest`, only the ones related to getting the current directory.

Fix #5965
Fix #7333
Close #6733

issue.title: Hitting a breakpoint opens a new instance of the file

repository.name: ptvsd
repository.description: Python debugger package for use with Visual Studio and Visual Studio Code.

issue.body:
This issue is same as microsoft/vscode-python#5139, microsoft/vscode-python#225 and microsoft/vscode-python#4166
which closed and those suggest updating python ext, but mine is already up to date[2020.2.63072].

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16190134/74835599-b6064580-5343-11ea-99ce-133f7351dea7.png)

Issues microsoft/vscode-python#5049 and microsoft/vscode-python#1313 are similar in nature.

and no, This is not the case of lowercase drive letters as said in https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-python/issues/2976#issuecomment-431946411

The problem here is that the breakpoints if marked in the original file, are carried over but can't be disabled from the new file. As well as breakpoints created in the new file are not migrated back to original file. i.e. the breakpoints are treated different. 

This leads to confusion in debugging as you just cannot see why the debugger is halting
If I want to remove a breakpoint, I have to use the breakpoints explorer. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16190134/74835963-712ede80-5344-11ea-92d0-b1a112ad6ac7.png)
This is the look of breakpoints explorer in debugger

And by habbit , assuming that the file being debugged is displayed, I start editing the file and save it, which propagates the contents to the original file, but the breakpoints in the original file are now ordered very differently, thus making the debugger stop everywhere. Which is just annoying.

The steps to reproduce the issue are mentioned here : 
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-python/issues/225#issue-273959633

and examples are here :
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-python/issues/4166#issue-403825856



However, When I created a new Project, I was unable to produce the same result.
Then I thought that It may be because I have multiple Launch configurations in my project,
but testing with two launch configs in the new project does not seem to reproduce the issue.

I will try to provide as much info I can on this

The python interpreter is a conda env and code was started from conda powershell prompt in both cases

System Info:

AMD R7 1700 @3GHZ
RAM 16GB, 52% usage
Multiple HDDs and SSDs
VSCode version 1.42.1
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16190134/74837056-a805f400-5346-11ea-9437-a114f8c6eb2c.png)

Python Extension version : 2020.2.63072

[conda_problem_env_packges_installed.txt](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-python/files/4225212/conda_problem_env_packges_installed.txt)


EDIT:
UNRELETED:
Why is Github linking /pull/1313 at microsoft/vscode-python#1313 ?
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16190134/74837895-7ee66300-5348-11ea-92d7-818e18f4e09a.png)

Where it links /issues/#<num> everywhere else?
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16190134/74837907-84dc4400-5348-11ea-9379-6f6a43e5c4b9.png)

issue.title: Prevent multiple collecting of the same file due to recursive symlinks

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.body:
Fixes: #624.  

The following directory structure will now be collected correctly.
```
.
 link -> .
 test_recursive.py
```
